Monte Carlo Simulation: Bagging vs Individual Kernels

Source: R/mc.R
mc.Rd

This function runs a Monte Carlo simulation comparing individual FastKernelSurvivalSVM models (one per kernel specification) against a Bagging ensemble fitted via fastsvm_bagging.

mc(
  n = 300,
  prop_cen = 0.3,
  kernels,
  B = 50,
  mtry = NULL,
  seed = NULL,
  cores = parallel::detectCores(),
  train_prop = 0.7,
  n_rep = 50L,
  .progress = TRUE
)

Arguments

n

Integer. Sample size per replication.

prop_cen

Numeric. Proportion of censoring (0 to 1). Default is 0.3.

kernels

A named list of kernel specifications. The same list is used for individual fits and for the Bagging ensemble.

B

Integer. Number of bootstrap samples for the Bagging model.

mtry

Integer or NULL. Number of variables to randomly sample at each split in the Bagging model (Random Subspace).

seed

Integer or NULL. Global seed for reproducibility. This seed is set once at the beginning of the simulation.

cores

Integer. Number of cores used by the Bagging model. This value is passed to fastsvm_bagging.

train_prop

Numeric. Proportion of data used for training (default 0.7). The remaining data is used for testing.

n_rep

Integer. Number of Monte Carlo replications.

.progress

Logical. If TRUE, show a progress bar during Monte Carlo replications (delegated to purrr::map()).

Value

A data.frame summarizing the C-index distribution for each model across replications, with columns:

  • Model: kernel name or "Bagging".

  • Mean_C_Index: mean C-index over replications.

  • SD_C_Index: standard deviation of the C-index.

  • Min_C_Index: minimum C-index.

  • Max_C_Index: maximum C-index.

The object also carries an attribute "cindex_matrix" which is a matrix of dimension n_rep x n_models containing the raw C-index values for each replication (rows) and model (columns).

Details

For each replication, the function:

  1. Generates a dataset via data_generation().

  2. Splits it into training and test sets.

  3. Fits one fastsvm model for each kernel in kernels and computes the test C-index via score.

  4. Fits a Bagging ensemble with fastsvm_bagging and computes its test C-index via score.

Bagging is always fitted in parallel according to the cores argument, using the internal parallelization provided by fastsvm_bagging. The Monte Carlo loop itself runs serially, but a global progress bar can be shown via .progress = TRUE.

The console output is slightly "embellished" with emojis (via the emo package, if available) to make the simulation more informative and visually pleasant.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
if (reticulate::py_module_available("sksurv") &&
    requireNamespace("mirai", quietly = TRUE) &&
    requireNamespace("purrr", quietly = TRUE)) {
  library(FastSurvivalSVM)

  # 1. Custom Kernel Factories
  make_wavelet <- function(A = 1) {
    force(A)
    function(x, z) {
      u <- (as.numeric(x) - as.numeric(z)) / A
      prod(cos(1.75 * u) * exp(-0.5 * u^2))
    }
  }

  make_poly <- function(degree = 3, coef0 = 1) {
    force(degree); force(coef0)
    function(x, z) (sum(as.numeric(x) * as.numeric(z)) + coef0)^degree
  }

  # 2. Kernel Specifications (rank_ratio = 0 for Regression / Time)
  kernel_mix <- list(
    linear   = list(kernel = "linear",
                    alpha  = 1,
                    rank_ratio = 0,
                    fit_intercept = TRUE),
    rbf      = list(kernel = "rbf",
                    alpha  = 0.5,
                    gamma  = 0.1,
                    rank_ratio = 0,
                    fit_intercept = TRUE),
    poly_std = list(kernel = "poly",
                    degree = 2L,
                    alpha  = 1,
                    rank_ratio = 0,
                    fit_intercept = TRUE),
    wavelet  = list(kernel = make_wavelet(A = 1),
                    alpha  = 1,
                    rank_ratio = 0,
                    fit_intercept = TRUE),
    poly_fun = list(kernel = make_poly(degree = 2L),
                    alpha  = 1,
                    rank_ratio = 0,
                    fit_intercept = TRUE)
  )

  # 3. Run Monte Carlo Simulation (e.g. 20 replications)
  results <- mc(
    n           = 300,
    prop_cen    = 0.3,
    kernels     = kernel_mix,
    B           = 50,
    mtry        = NULL,
    seed        = 5,
    cores       = parallel::detectCores(),
    train_prop  = 0.7,
    n_rep       = 20,
    .progress   = TRUE
  )

  print(results)
}
} # }
